I think with Biden as President there is a greater chance of boycotting the Olympics. But I feel that this action would heavily depend on public responses to the Uighur crisis.

Such a measure would be out of character for the Biden administration, which values stability and amicable foreign relations. One thing it does do, however, is allow itself to be swayed to some degree by public sentiment. In 2019, there was an anti-China wave among progressives and conservatives alike in light of the Hong Kong protests. When public opinion shifted toward Palestine in the US with the 2021 Israel-Palestine conflict, the Biden administration did show a sympathy toward Palestine uncharacteristic of American leadership.

Thanks to all who figured the base case at 3.5%. I go much lower based on the inside view: The last Democratic President who decided to force a boycott of an Olympics during a period of concern about inflation, societal breakdown, and Cold War didn’t fair so well in his re-election prospects, losing in one of the biggest electoral college landslides ever. I don’t think the current president is ignorant of all the parallels with the situation in 1980 or how much it contributed to a sense of the country heading in the wrong direction. Outside view: the enormous power of the Olympics for generating cash for U.S. companies is even more pronounced compared with then. I think the “diplomatic boycott” will suffice to underline the USG’s concern over the CCP’s human rights abuses.

There's little reason to think that the Biden administration, which prizes normalized relations and continuity with foreign countries, would take this drastic step without some explicit provocation. But the odds are non-zero given there are a number of hot-button issues including trade, the South China Sea, the detention of a large number of Uighurs, etc.
